1793.Subtitle: Every second breath we take comes from the ocean.

1800.Subtitle: But this won’t last much longer.

1807.Subtitle: We’re in the process of killing around 96% of ocean life.

1819.Subtitle: That’s what happened some 252 million years ago in an event known as “the great dying” largely due to global warming.

1830.Subtitle: In our lifetime, we are releasing enormous amounts of carbon dioxide, or CO2, into the atmosphere. This is absorbed by the oceans and acidifies the water.

1845.Subtitle: It decreases our oceans’ pH – its levels of acidity – which has deadly consequences for much of marine life.

1854.Subtitle: Shells and skeletons dissolve, and marine animals’ physiology changes.

1860.Subtitle: If we fail to act, what will happen to them… and to us?

2035.Subtitle: 2050 represents a tipping point for the future of the oceans.

2042.Subtitle: With increasingly warmer temperatures around the world, we are depleting the oceans of oxygen and suffocating all lifeforms.

2052.Subtitle: These animals don’t only sustain the rest of marine life. They ultimately sustain us. Human beings, and our economies, cultures, and communities, depend on them.

2102.Subtitle: If we don't drastically reduce our CO2 production, and limit the planet’s temperature rise to under 1.5°C, the whole ocean system may collapse.

2114.Subtitle: This won’t only affect the ocean. Many land animals depend on fish to survive.

2122.Subtitle: And so do we, our economies and our cultures.

2127.Subtitle: To prevent this, we need to reduce our carbon footprint.

2133.Subtitle: We still have the power to stop this catastrophe.

2138.Subtitle: But the time to act is NOW.
